awd_titl_txt: Implementation Project: Transforming Computational STEM Education at Claflin University
awd_abstract_narration:
Implementation Projects in the Historically Black Colleges and Universities - Undergraduate program provide support to design, implement, study and assess comprehensive institutional efforts to increase the numbers of students and the quality of their preparation by strengthening science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) education and research. This implementation project at Claflin University focuses on the disciplines of biology, chemistry, computer science and mathematics to provide an array of computational technologies in order to support and educate the next-generation of data scientists who can work in a multi-disciplinary environment.  Claflin University has a proven record of graduating a significant number of African-American students in STEM fields and through this implementation project that number is projected to increase. The project is guided and informed by an on-going evaluation.

The goals of the proposed project are to increase graduation and placement rates of students in the STEM workforce; to infuse research and education in a STEM-based computational curriculum; to promote computational science research to improve the quality of experiences and prepare STEM students to compete in a global society; and to use the strengths and assets of core partners to propel students towards a STEM career. The project will create relationships with federal and national laboratories, industry and other universities. The project involves faculty and undergraduate students to conduct research in the areas of metabolites and biomolecules using analytical instrumentation and methodology; in methods for retrieving and analyzing biological data; as well as in optimization, computational complexity, statistical modeling and machine learning.

por.por_cntn:
Under the Implementation Project: Transforming Computational STEM Education at Claflin University (CU) several outcomes were seen from 2014 to 2021 and is outlined below.

To improve student-faculty mentored research and conference presentation: Several databases were utilized for computational research such as KEGG (Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes) and HGMD (Human Gene Mutation Database). These databases provide enhanced opportunity for our students to carry out research at the frontier level. Students had the opportunity to be trained on state of the art lab equipment at CU which made them more competitive to get accepted for internships.       

HBCU-UP supported the enhancement of our computational facilities by providing MATLAB software, Statistics Toolbox, Bioinformatics Toolbox, Spartan 10 subscription, Gaussian G09W and GVW5 license subscription; these databases and software package helped in both research and integrating research into the course materials. Equipment that were purchase and maintain during this project is NMR, Spectroelectrochemical system, Bomb Calorimeter, repaired Agilent UV/Vis Spectrophotomer, Chiller for the XRD systems, Sample Case sample changer, ultralow freezer, explosion proof refrigerators, Computers and hardware accessories. Also, HBCU-UP funding were also used to support a robotics laboratory.

Dr. Ramier Sriram, Associate Professor in the Department of Mathematics and Computer Science and Dr. Hongxia Zhang, who was hired under HBCU-UP supplement as Post-Doctoral Associate to work with faculty in the Computational Research Lab are now fully supported by the institution; Dr. Zhang is now a Visiting Assistant Professor of Chemistry.

Collaborations and partnerships were established with the following institutions and organizations: Boeing Company; University of Central Florida Institute for Simulation & Training; University of Georgia; Prisma Health of Greenville Health System: Medical Experience Academy (MedEX); Harvard Medical School: HMX; MOU with Clemson Department of Bioengineering; SC Afterschool Alliance; Campbell School Pharmacy; The Neveah Group; Lincoln University; Presbyterian College; Savannah River National Laboratory; and MOU with Richland School District Two in Columbia, SC;   

Funding from HBCU-UP has been instrumental in provided release time and summer pay for Dr. Sriram Ramaier, Computer Science Professor, to devote time in the preparation of an application to the Accreditation Board for Engineering and Technology (ABET). by working on an ABET Self Study of our Computer Science program. The Computer Science Program at Claflin University received ABET accreditation in October 2019, effect retroactively to October 2017. 

American Chemical Society (ACS) five-year report was completed and submitted to the ACS for affirmation of re-accreditation. The Chemistry department?s accreditation was reaffirmed by the ACS Fall 2017. ?The ACS's Committee on Professional Training (CPT) ?commended Claflin's administration for supporting a very well-funded and well-equipped program.  The outcomes of the students following graduation are exceptional with many pursing postgraduate studies in the STEM fields. The Committee congratulated the faculty for improving the courses and described the diversity among the faculty as exceptional?.

A nursing program was established at Claflin University in 2016; it?s the only HBCU with an RN to BSN or MSN program in SC. The baccalaureate degree program in nursing receive accreditation by the Commission on Collegiate Nursing Education in June 2019, effect retroactively to October 2018.

HBCU-UP program manager (Pamela Shuler) assist Dr. Tisdale with the Cybersecurity Consortium (CECOR) at Claflin University. After the inception of the CECOR program, we were able to inaugurate a Cybersecurity minor at CU. The Applied Computing minor was developed during HBCU-UP project. During this project period, the mass communications track was updated to remove one course and add a digital design course. Also, Claflin University revitalized the General Education Curriculum; the new curriculum provides space for minors and certificate offerings. All the mentioned were impacts on development of disciplines.

HBCU-UP scholars received accepted into the following schools and programs: Arizona State University (PhD in Applied Mathematics); Clark Atlanta University (MS in Biology); North Carolina Central University (PhD in Integrated Bioscience); North Carolina State University (MS in Analytics); Carnegie Mellon University (MS in Mechanical Engineering); Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute (MS in Quantitative Finance and Risk Analytics); The University of Arizona (PhD in Applied Mathematics); Tufts University (School Pharmacy); Ohio University (Post Baccalaureate Premedical); Rice University (PhD in Biochemistry); Purdue University (PhD in Biochemistry); The University of Missouri (Dual MSs in Applied Mathematics and Economics); Louisiana State University (School of Veterinary Medicine); Medical University of South Carolina (Pharmacy School); Lincoln Memorial University (MS in Anatomical Sciences); Citadel University (Clinical Counseling); Claflin University (MS in Biotechnology); George Washington University (MS of Science in Computer Science); Towson University (Bridge to Doctorate Program with MS in Biology and PhD in Biomedical Sciences); Tulane University (MS in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology); University of Arkansas (MS in Cell and Molecular Biology); and University of Missouri St. Louise (MS in Computer Science); The University of South Carolina (MS in Biology) and The University of Texas Austin (MS in Business Analytics).
